    So, how did they become billionaires? There are many reasons. The Economist went on to say:

    "Among many reasons, they were developers who simply rode with land prices."

    The reality in Hong Kong today is a noisy market place, crowded with thousands of entrepreneurs who are, in the final analysis, owners of SMEs and glorified sweat shops. They perform useful roles. Please do not get me wrong. They provide employment for the masses. They provide hope. But the world has changed.

    In the economic food chain of the WTO, the new regime, it is a big fish eat small fish scenario. Hong Kong's cousins, their brethrens, from mainland China, are

Column: 858

beginning to eat Hong Kong SMEs and sweat shop owners as fish feed.

    The truth of the matter is this. In Hong Kong, a few tycoons and their gargantuan holding companies, like Cheung Kong and Hutchinson Whampoa, dominate the Hong Kong economy. People do not see that. Together, these companies and the tycoons employ hundreds of thousands of workers, and their decisions influence the destiny of Hong Kong and HongKongers. These tycoons own an eclectic group of businesses, sometimes totally unrelated. They are like the mini-government of Hong Kong. Some say the only government of Hong Kong. These tycoons own what? They own banks, the ports, power stations, telecommunications, the media, retail, yes, supermarkets and, of course, real estate. They are the economic equivalents of our Temasek-linked companies. But the similarities end here. They are powerful. They are rich. GLCs are rich, but GLCs are not powerful.

    The Hong Kong tycoons and their companies are answerable to no one, but themselves, their shareholders and their boards of directors. But usually they have the biggest chunks of shares in their own companies. So they are basically answerable to shareholders of which they form a large part. And they are very profitable companies. The profits only accrue to the shareholders. In contrast, GLCs are not powerful.

    Today, we are debating the role of Government-linked companies, Temasek-linked companies in this House. TLCs are answerable not only to shareholders, because some are listed, and their boards of directors but, of course, to Temasek Holdings, which has to answer to Government. That is why we are here today. And Government has to account to MPs who have to account to their constituencies. So, talk about transparency, talk about accountability, our GLCs, our TLCs in particular, are extremely accountable. Anybody can move a motion or file a Question. In my 10 years here, I have heard several questions and answers on why these TLCs went into this business, why this business failed, and the Minister

Column: 859

for Finance dutifully stood up and gave an answer which, I think, most of us accept, while some disagree altogether.

    I am using this example to drive home the first of many messages in the New World, in the new regime of WTO. And this first message I want to drive home is this - that TLCs are not villains. In a global economy, a few companies dominate. This happens in Singapore. It happens to be GLCs because of our history. It happens in Hong Kong. A few tycoon-dominated companies control and run Hong Kong. And the rest of us, SMEs, sweat shop owners, have to feed off these TLCs, tycoon-owned businesses. It is the same everywhere. Unfortunately, too many Singaporeans love to hate our Temasek-linked companies and now that has been extended to NTUC-linked companies. They blame TLCs for the death of local entrepreneurs. They say, dismantle the TLCs, and then everything will be fine. All entrepreneurs will mushroom. They will grow, they will flourish, and then they will be big. But I wish it were true and life is so simple.

    Mr Leong Horn Kee and Mr Inderjit Singh, please take a look at Hong Kong and tell me, where are the Bill Gates? Tell me, where are the Jeff Bezos, where are the Dells, where are the Intels, where are the HPs? You do not find them. None. They are not there. The gatekeepers of Hong Kong are really small entrepreneurs. They are the unsung heroes of the economy, but the people underpinning them are just a few big tycoon-dominated companies.

    You will not find a Bill Gates in Hong Kong, but you will find a Mr Li Ka Shing. Hongkongers love him, and they call him "Superman", chiu yan (in Cantonese). Chiu yan means Superman. Mr Li's hold on the economy is formidable. His two companies - Hutchinson Whampoa and Cheung Kong - dominate the economy of Hong Kong. But unlike some of our CEOs of GLCs, Mr Li is revered, respected and worshipped. Here, Singaporeans blame TLCs for being too big and crowding out

Column: 860

businesses. But, think again, Mr Li is held up as a model entrepreneur in Hong Kong even as his eclectic empire grows. Some people are saying in Hong Kong that he is also crowding out entrepreneurs. But, by and large, this is a voice from the minority.

    Mr Li is a hero in Hong Kong and not a villain. He provides jobs, thousands of jobs, for Hongkongers. And Hongkongers believe in Mr Li. In fact, Hong Kong is worried every now and then that he might just move his Hutchinson Whampoa and Cheung Kong offshore. Each time Hongkongers feel that he might be doing so, he came out to reassure them. But our TLCs have never said they want to move overseas. Our TLCs have said they want to go overseas to do business and bring the money back. The question of TLCs rooting themselves with the Singapore economy and providing jobs for Singapore has never been an issue here, which I am glad. The issue of Hutchinson Whampoa moving overseas has always been rumoured and always dispelled by Mr Li himself.

    But Mr Li, although he is a superman, is not infallible. His company has made some less than good investments. Or even today, Hutchinson Whampoa's share has been hammered from the high. Before the year 2000, it was something like HK$120 per share. Today, it is something like HK$60. I do not know the rate today. But, last week, I saw it was hovering below HK$60.

    In the 1980s, Mr Li's investment in a Canadian oil company did not live up to market expectations. It under-performed for many years. Mr Li's investment in Rabbit, if you remember, a telephony company in Britain, was another flop, a failure. But few remember his failed investments. We all remember his successes, and so it should be, because he is a very successful businessman.

    This example brings me to a second message which I want to bring home - that Singaporeans should be a little bit more forgiving, if some of our TLCs have made some bad investments in the short term. Even a highly successful company,

Column: 861

like Hutchinson Whampoa, has made bad investments. Singaporeans, in fact, should be worried if our TLCs make no investments and think short term.

    There is a third point in my comparison, and this is not a major point I want to make, but I thought this is the mood of the day, and I would say it. Singaporeans are having so much angst over foreign talent policy. If TLCs were dismantled, for example, who do we sell to? Well, possibly sell them to some foreign investors maybe, who have the money and the interest. If so, there will be a lot more foreign talents in Singapore.

    Both Hong Kong and China regard Mr Li as a patriot, but Mr Li did not grow his stable of companies by employing Chinese and Hongkongers for a long time. For as long as I can remember, Mr Li has always had a policy of hiring the best, and his most senior management are foreign talents, and foreign talents I mean Caucasians. In Hong Kong, they say kwai lao. Here, in Singapore, we have a few foreign talents in GLCs, TLCs, and already Singaporeans are feeling the heat. Actually, we should have more. Because if you want TLCs to be global companies of distinction, we really need to harvest the best from around the world. So I asked those people who are lobbying for the dismantling of TLCs, are you sure you want to dismantle TLCs? Because, you know, what they say, be careful of what you wish, you might just get it.

    I hope I have put into perspective a world without TLCs. Still, I think it is right that Temasek Holdings is determined to sell some TLCs even if it wants to grow others, find partners for others and merge others. But we are reassured, through the Temasek Charter, and the statements in the press, that there will be no fire sale. We are not going to sell. We should not sell the TLCs for a song. Our national assets are not for lelong. And this brings me to my last point.

    The management of Temasek Holdings has come up with a Temasek Charter. At the top of its Charter, it says, "Temasek Holdings holds and manages the

Column: 862

Singapore Government's investments in companies for the long term benefit of Singapore." I find this most reassuring. How many companies can put up that kind of mission statement? The Temasek Charter makes it clear from the very outset that every Singaporean has a stake in Temasek even if we do not hold a single share in any of the Temasek-linked companies. I think we should be proud of Temasek. Temasek really is our future. Our SMEs, our small mom and pop shops do deserve encouragement. They should be encouraged to grow. We should level the playing field. But they are unable to reach out and anchor to the big powers, the big players in the West.

    When we were young, we all know this refrain in essay. The teacher always says, "Singapore is a small island with limited resources." I think, today, we can tell the teacher to tell Singaporeans that "Singapore is a small island with Temasek". If Temasek is our future, we should chart its future together. And for this reason, I really welcome this debate on Temasek Charter in this House moved by Mr Leong Horn Kee and Mr Inderjit Singh. In some ways, I agree with them. For too long, Temasek has been a passive holding company. Its mode of operation and its mission were a little bit opaque, a little bit over our head. I hope that it is slowly changing. I think it is changing. And this new management is a catalyst for change.

    I have a dream that one day Temasek will be a General Electric with a diversified stable of businesses, each of which is a world or, at least, a regional brand name. It will take Temasek decades to reach this goal. It took Jack Welch a good 20 to 30 years to finalise the shape of General Electric that we know today.

    Certainly some companies should be divested; some merged; some acquired, but that is best left to the management of Temasek. But reading the Charter, I am confident that Temasek management has the ambitions and determination to succeed. With this Charter, Temasek is really chartering into uncharted waters, because there are no MBA case studies

Column: 863

for Temasek to emulate and analyse. Temasek Holdings will have to write its own MBA case study, for somebody else to study in the decades to come. In time, we will know how Temasek has remained faithful to the Charter, how it has linked the future to Singapore, and how it has performed against its own benchmark. I think today's debate is useful. We should revisit this debate in the next few years.

    But, Mdm Deputy Speaker, before I end, I hope I have time to talk about the NTUC-linked companies. Actually NTUC-linked companies are not part of today's Motion. NTUC-linked companies are largely formed for Singaporeans and, in fact, NTUC-linked companies - I know it, because I had been in NTUC for sometime now - were formed precisely against the Yellow Pages rule. The Yellow Pages rule says that if the name is in the Yellow Pages, let us, say, a supermarket, it should get out. But when FairPrice was formed, there were few supermarkets. NTUC FairPrice went in basically because the price of basic commodities was too high. And NTUC went in to provide competition against the local retailers. The results, after 20-odd years, I think, prove that it has succeeded. NTUC prices today are among the lowest prices in the retail scene. Column: 864

opens up a big supermarket chain in some parts of America, the residents welcome it, because it lowers the cost of commodities by a huge margin. But, of course, shopkeepers around the town would be upset. It is something we have to live with.     One last word about academic advice. I have left the university for the last 10 years now, and of course not as well known as Michael Porter and all that. We are here, we know our business better. We are here because our destiny is here. They are in Boston, they are in London. Their business is to write papers, to gain a world-wide audience, to win the Nobel Prize. Our duty is to provide for our future, for our children's future.

What it means is that the knowledge of the value of the company is not shared equally between the shareholder and the managers. Logically, it can never be, as who, other than the managers who are engaged in the day-to-day running of the company, are better acquainted with the business and the value of the company. In an MBO, any price that the managers put to the shareholders will always result in a net gain for them. It can never be that, in the

Column: 887

case where the company is on the whole generally profitable, the managers are prepared to risk more than $300 million of their own money on a gamble. In the present context, it is arguable that risk money is directly proportional to the returns and inversely proportional to the risk that they assume. The question then is, if the managers are going to make money from the exercise, how much will it be? At best, the potential value of the company can only be an estimate. Of course, it has been said that tenders were called for and the proposals of the various interested were evaluated. However, it should be noted that price fixing in buying and selling is almost as much of an art as it is a science. What parties would typically do in order to ascertain the value of the company is to conduct a due diligence exercise on the company to verify the accounts and the corporate books. Again, anyone who has undertaken work in the area of mergers and acquisitions will readily tell you that no amount of due diligence is going to put an outside party on par with the managers in knowing and understanding the true value of the company. So, the point is while a tender may be called for, it will not always result in the seller ascertaining the correct value of the company.

    There is therefore a general perception that the sale of Government assets, in this case, if it went to the managers, is going to make some Singaporeans very rich. The greatest travesty on enterprise and entrepreneurship will come if the managers are able to asset strip the company for a handsome profit after they have acquired it from the Government. The question then is in selling State assets to the managers, can the Government provide the assurance that these buyers will continue with the business and give comfort to the employees that their jobs will be secure; that the buyers will not asset strip the company; that if asset stripping was the intention, a better way to do it would be for the Government to do it itself; that the sale to the managers is the best way to maximise the value of these assets?

Column: 888



    In the final analysis, while the Government is intent on divesting non-core assets, it should not do so in a hurry and, in the process, run the risk of selling these assets on the cheap.

    My final point is on the small and medium enterprises in Singapore. The complaint that one often hears within some circles, and was referred to in this afternoon's debate, is that the presence of GLCs stifles much of the ability of the SMEs to compete and grow their businesses. While there may be some merits to the argument, one must not forget the converse side to the argument, ie, the entry of the GLCs to their business turfs has helped to raise the standard and quality of the business services. Think of what the quality of motor workshops would be like today if a GLC had not entered into the same arena. Small and medium enterprises should not think that it is their God given right not to expect competition from the bigger boys. In this debate, I believe the issue is not whether GLCs should enter into the business of small and medium enterprises. For, if this was the case, the absence of GLCs is not going to prevent other bigger boys from entering the scene. The issue is whether the bigger boys, and in this case the GLCs, are able to dominate the business of the small and medium enterprise simply because of unfair competition. Are the rules and the practices of the market place stacked in favour of the GLCs? Here, I welcome the proposal of the EISC that there should be some form of competition law to ensure that the playing field is a level one, irrespective of whether you are a big or a small player. The point is that the small and medium enterprises should not expect free rides from any quarters. They must earn their spurs by competing in the market place and survive. Only then can they hope to nurture any aspiration of competing on a bigger world stage.

    Mr Ong Kian Min (Tampines): Mdm Deputy Speaker, the effectiveness of Government-linked companies (GLCs) and Government agencies in driving the economic development of Singapore since independence is undeniable. A report by the US Embassy in Singapore

Column: 889

recognised Singapore GLCs to be well run, efficient and profitable, unlike typical state-owned enterprises in many other countries. It also acknowledged that the major GLCs, including Singapore Airlines, Neptune Orient Lines, Chartered Semiconductor, Keppel Corporation and Sembawang Corporation are publicly listed and among the best known corporate names locally and regionally.

    Indeed, we should be proud of our GLCs and Government agencies which contributed about 13% and 9% respectively to our Gross Domestic Product in 1998. However, the very success of the GLCs and Government enterprises has reached a point where private enterprises feel crowded out of local businesses and has sparked calls for a refocus of the role of Government in business.

    An open and competitive economy like Singapore will need to have rules to curb excessive economic power being concentrated in and wielded by any particular group, thereby resulting in inequitable conditions and stifling of competition and choice. A spread of economic clout is necessary to ensure a balanced, healthy and sustained growth of the economy. It is thus timely that the Entrepreneurship and Internationalisation Sub-Committee (EISC) has made several recommendations that seek to promote a level playing field and provide fair competition and fair opportunities for all enterprises, big and small, Government and private, to succeed. Similarly, Temasek Holdings' declaration of its Charter is a positive move that provides better clarity and transparency in Government philosophies and dealings.

    Madam, my vision and hope is that, over time, we will create an open, competitive economic environment:

    (a) where GLCs and SMEs will work closely together and symbiotically to build a vibrant and thriving economy, both domestically as well as externally, where each has a stake and each plays a complementary role, and where one is comfortable dealing with the other,

Column: 890

because of mutual trust, understanding and respect;

    (b) where GLCs understand and focus on their core businesses, strengths and competencies and tap on, partner, groom and nurture SMEs to break new ground, develop innovative ideas and technologies and venture into new businesses, markets and customers together;

    (c) where the distinction between GLCs and local enterprises become increasingly blurred, as these terms become interchangeable when GLCs get divested, publicly listed or bought out by management or private equity, and budding local enterprises and start-ups form joint ventures with GLCs or get acquired by GLCs, groomed, nurtured and get spun off again.

    However, based on the comments and anecdotal stories told by local private business people of their encounters with GLCs and Government agencies, I fear that we are still a long way from reaching and achieving such a happy state of coexistence. I sense that there may be a divide between the management of GLCs who pride themselves in having a strong culture, good corporate governance, transparencies and checks and controls, and the bosses of SMEs who feel proud being brash, daring, nimble and entrepreneurial. A lot more needs to be done and must be done to bridge the divide. Otherwise, the divide will widen into a gulf filled with misunderstanding and distrust, where each side refuses to work with the other nor share information or resources and prefers to work with its own kind, or simply goes its own way and does its own things. This is divisive. We will not have a cohesive front to tackle our economic challenges. On the whole, we will end up the poorer for it. More needs to be done for GLCs to actively engage SMEs and gain their trust, and for SMEs to improve and upgrade to secure the confidence of the GLCs that they are up to the mark and will be able to deliver.

    What is the situation existing today? Today, more so than ever before, I find that our local private enterprises are

Column: 891

fearful of the competition coming from not just the GLCs but corporatised Government agencies and larger companies as the domestic market place becomes increasingly crowded and keenly competitive. The common complaint is centred on having an unlevel playing field and being crowded out. Our smaller local companies find it hard to compete against the GLCs who have, over the years, as a result of financial prudence, sound management and proper controls, grown even stronger, leaner, hungrier and better managed than ever before.

    I recall that at the millennium conference held a couple of years back, when asked by a member from the audience about competition from GLCs, Senior Minister of State Khaw Boon Wan, who was then Permanent Secretary of the Ministry of Trade and Industry, replied, "We put good men to run our GLCs well. If a GLC does not perform, we change the man." I think that sent chills down the spines of many of the private sector bosses present then. But having well-managed and competitive GLCs is not necessarily a bad thing. Our GLCs are not necessarily a bad thing to building internationally competitive Singapore companies.

    It was mentioned that, in the past, we did not have sufficient private capital to fund the likes of SIA and NOL, and therefore the Government had to step in to provide the necessary funding. And that times have changed and therefore the Government should not be involved in business nowadays, and should leave it to the private sector. But if we think about that, even today, if we see the future is in wafer fabrication, which non-Government related industrial conglomerate can come up with the money to take up a meaningful equity stake in a billion dollar wafer fab plant? Can our wafer fab initiative be left totally to the private sector? And if not for the group of Hong Kong investors SM persuaded to invest in the Suntec City, which local group would be daring enough to invest in a Convention Centre the size of Suntec City at that time?

Column: 892



    Madam, I think the Government and the Government-linked companies continue to have an important role to play even today, to build world-class international companies. If, for example, there is good business in a particular area, should we identify a GLC, promote it, manage it properly, so that it grows to be substantial enough to compete with the best in the world, and then later divest it? Or should we promote a private sector company instead? There is no one common strategy that fits across the broad range of industries. Some industries, like wafer fab, port management and airlines, must at least for now be left to the GLCs or statutory boards. Others like pastries, security systems and trade directories should clearly be left to private enterprise. The question is, where and how they should be involved and still allow room for creativity and private enterprise and entrepreneurship to flourish? And the objectives and rules must be clearly spelt out and be made transparent, and certain anti-competitive practices must not be condoned.

    My colleague, Mr Ahmad Magad, will tell you that a few years ago when he was planning to set up a factory for his company in the Suzhou Industrial Park, the authority that issues the construction permit hinted to him that if he were to use a related design house and contractor, the permit would be issued in a matter of days. But if he were to choose to use his own designer and contractor, then the permit may take much longer, and even months, before it is issued. It seems that in our regionalisation drive and software transfer to other countries, some of such bad practices have been brought back into Singapore and have slowly crept into our business environment. This is not rampant as yet, but I think a larger company can quite easily say to a supplier, "If you want this business from us, then you must also use our sister company for other services." We must not allow this practice to develop and must nip it in the bud. This is beginning to happen in some sectors, and I hope that we will take the initiative and take firm action to nip it in the bud.

Column: 893



    While a case can be made out on why the continued presence of GLCs is necessary, it is very difficult to convince the public and rationalise why statutory boards are now entering the market to compete with private enterprises. With the move towards privatisation, liberalisation and deregulation, the Government must maintain a neutral position in order to be effective as a regulator and national agency. Is it not incongruous that SPRING Singapore which spearheads SME development and upgrading owns two subsidiaries (PSB Corporation and PSB Certification) that compete with the private sector? These two entities operate as commercial organisations offering training, consultancy, technology and testing services and certification, leading to complaints of unfair advantage that these subsidiaries have against the private sector consultants. Is there a real need for statutory boards to form companies for them to achieve its mission? A*STAR, the new name for the National Science and Technology Board, formed Exploit Technologies Private Limited, which the Agency has termed as its commercialisation arm. Should CISCO, as a statutory board, venture beyond its armed protection services to compete head on with the private sector to sell alarms and security systems, services and facilities?

    Madam, what local SMEs greatly need is to have GLCs help open doors for them, particularly overseas. The GLCs have the advantage of brand reputation, network, contacts, connections and deep pockets. The SMEs are looking for a small piece of the action. The feedback from private bosses is that GLCs want to bao chek, that means to take all, and bao yian, that means to win all. If they learn a good idea from the SMEs, instead of working with the SMEs, they would take the idea and do it themselves. GLCs should work hard to dispel and correct this misconception.

    On the other hand, local businessmen have told me that the MNCs are more open to tapping the local support industries and outsourcing non-core activities to them. Take Hewlett Packard, for example. Throughout the years, it has certainly provided many opportunities

Column: 894

to our local businessmen in the electronic manufacturing services and support industry, and given them a crucial leg up to help them start on their way to becoming world-class companies.

    Not until recent times, when market consolidation pushes GLCs to focus on their core businesses, GLCs were aiming to be conglomerates, growing and expanding into all kinds of businesses with no regard to their strategic relevance. GLCs can gain in harnessing the creativity and entrepreneurship initiative of the local enterprises by partnering them in developing solutions that have market potential. It can be a win-win proposition for both the SMEs and GLCs as a partnership of complementary strength can be forged. Many of the budding technology companies lack the opportunity to build a track record to commercialise their solutions. GLCs and Government can provide the test bed for the solutions to gain recognition. Some of these companies are even willing to forgo commercial gains to build up their track record or even offer options for the companies to take up stakes in these companies. But not many got any headway as most of the GLCs and Government agencies prefer to take the option of DIY (do-it-yourself) or use the tried and tested. If major corporations of Singapore do not support the SMEs, how can we expect them to convince potential overseas buyers?

    The Government has various grants and financial assistance schemes in place to foster innovation. But what is lacking is the creation of an environment where local enterprises can easily find opportunities to deploy their solutions. Developing project or client references is important. It is also through larger scale deployment and commercialisation that the innovative solution can be tested for its robustness and effectiveness, and stimulate continuing improvements.

    Madam, local business associations' response to the SME 21 has been lukewarm. The feeling is that SME 21 will follow the fate of its predecessor, 1998 SME Masterplan, which lost its momentum when the Singapore economy

Column: 895

picked up and the MNCs returned to Singapore. There is therefore a need to dedicate special attention and focus on SMEs, even though the economy is starting to pick up. In many advanced countries, like USA and Japan, the government agencies set up to look after the interests of SMEs solely. Therefore, this debate on how we can support the growth of our private enterprises and entrepreneurship in Singapore is timely. I believe Singapore entrepreneurs and businesses too have big dreams. The Government and GLCs can act as a catalyst to unleash the potential of the Singapore Enterprise. By supporting the SMEs, we are nurturing a culture and a mindset of innovation and creativity that marks the making of a great nation.

    Dr Amy Khor Lean Suan (Hong Kah): Mdm Deputy Speaker, the Temasek Charter raises an issue which the Minister of State for Trade and Industry, Mr Raymond Lim's Entrepreneurship and Internationalisation Sub-Committee (EISC) dealt with in their recently released report. The main focus of the report is the role of the Government in business.

    Public discourse has, of late, focused almost exclusively on the issue of CPF after Senior Minister of State for Trade and Industry Mr Tharman Shanmugaratnam's sub-committee released its report. However, I submit that the issue of the role of Government in business deserves equally intense scrutiny from Members of this House and the public. This is because it raises very fundamental questions about the Government's position with regard to the nurturing of local enterprises, the responsibility it places upon itself for shaping Singapore's economic landscape and hence, the nature of government and its relation with the body politic.

    In my view, the Temasek Charter cannot and should not be divorced from the broader context of what the EISC document discusses. This is also in line with the essence of the Motion before this House. Moreover, it is noted that parts of the Temasek Charter, especially the

Column: 896

section on the raison d'etre of GLCs, are in fact similar to those in the EISC document.

    I therefore would like to deal with both the Temasek Charter and the EISC recommendations in my speech, under what I term as the four "Ds" of the Government in business. The first "D" refers to delineation. We need to delineate clearly the markers for Government in business. This would, among others, help reduce allegations from the private sector of encroachment and crowding out of their businesses by GLCs.

    The EISC's recommendations regarding the Government's role in business cover not only Temasek Holdings but also individual Ministries and statutory boards. The EISC report is an excellent, well-thought-out and generally balanced report. There are a good number of wise and highly quotable statements from the document, three of which are particularly memorable to me and which provide good rules of thumb for delineating the boundary conditions of Government in business. These are, firstly, "We should not corporatise for corporatisation's sake." I strongly support the EISC's recommendation that statutory boards should as far as possible not corporatise regulatory functions because these are often monopoly functions and will lead to rent seeking behaviour by the enterprise.

    There would be a natural tendency for the public to perceive, rightly or wrongly, that the enterprise will resist simplifying rules and regulations as this could lead to a loss of revenue in fees and charges. Hence, the often heard refrain that the Government's fees and charges are high and should be cut.

    The IRAS, for instance, was previously criticised, in The Straits Times of 9th January 1997, for announcing its staff increments and bonuses took into account the amount of tax revenue collected. This led the public to infer that the IRAS staff had every incentive to maximise its tax collection!

Column: 897



    Like the EISC, I submit that it will be better to keep activities of statutory boards that are strategic to their missions as public functions, even if the activities can be organised to attract commercial returns. We should not corporatise for corporatisation's sake or just because everyone is jumping on the bandwagon. In this respect, if corporatisation is deemed necessary, the EISC mentions the use of the National HealthGroup model, which I wholeheartedly support.

    The second rule of thumb, as recommended by the EISC, is, "Temasek Holdings should compel GLCs to scale up their core competencies to build global businesses, as opposed to concentrating on the local market to build a diverse range of unrelated businesses." Some GLCs (such as SembCorp Industries and NOL) and corporatised enterprises of statutory boards (such as Ascendas) have already initiated this aggressively. Other GLCs and corporatised entities should also strive to do the same. Their reliance on the local market should be reduced and the temptation to invest in a diverse range of unrelated businesses to improve their bottomline or simply to justify their existence should be resisted. This would minimise the crowding out effect by GLCs which many SMEs complain they suffer from.

    Over the last three decades, GLCs have proliferated and taken on a life of their own. As noted in Business Times, 3rd June 2002, Singapore Technologies, for instance, has spawned so many subsidiaries that if its new Chief Executive, Peter Seah, were to visit one a day, it would reportedly take him up till 2005 to complete his rounds.

    Hence, any major attempt to divest or rationalise the GLCs could trigger a chain reaction, upsetting an entire apple cart of entrenched interests, institutional arrangements and corporate culture and agenda. Fortunately, as noted by the EISC, many GLCs are professionally run, profitable, listed on the bourse, and own reputable and thus valuable brand names that should not be destroyed purely to

Column: 898

silence the large contingent of GLC critics and cynics.

    Nevertheless, history does contain some lessons for us. The 70s and 80s were the era of the conglomerate. It became fashionable among businesses in the US to integrate vertically, horizontally, or even sideways, to cover the entire, or even out of the value chain. The result was a mish-mash of business units often unrelated to the original function. The holding company of the conglomerate, in effect, became a kind of internal stock market, allocating funds to its subsidiaries on the basis of financial performance.

    By the late 80s and early 90s, it became evident that this strategy created large unwieldy corporate creatures without the agility to compete against more nimble firms that chipped away at their respective businesses.

    Research in the US has shown that the decline of these conglomerates stems from the enormous difficulty of managing a diversity of unrelated operations. The reaction was to return to "core competencies" and a painful dismantling of these large business units. The semi-conductor business, for example, now organises itself around chip designers and foundries which are, in fact, sub-contractors to the former.

    There is a danger that GLCs and Government agencies may sometimes fall into the trap of acting in the manner of the now discredited corporate conglomerates. I speak from my personal experience. During the heydays of the property market boom in the mid-90s, not a few non-property GLCs were tempted by the astounding profits one could make from property investment. To be fair, GLCs were not the only firms to succumb to that temptation. On hindsight, property investment could indeed have delivered superior shareholder returns, but most firms did not exit quick enough.

    Thus many of these firms came to grief when the bubble burst, causing them to abandon their grand plans to turn into property players. Many of them have

Column: 899

since unwound or are unwinding unrelated businesses to focus on what they do best, for instance, Delgro and NatSteel. Madam, I hope that GLCs will be ever mindful of this chapter of their history and not turn back the clock.

    The third rule of thumb refers to the well known "Yellow Pages" rule. Instead of endorsing the EISC's recommended Yellow Pages rule, the Temasek Charter has, instead, chosen the opposite route - seeking to build on the best attributes of Singapore's unique GLC's model. Rather than destroying the value of GLCs which first took shape more than three decades ago, Temasek has chosen what is probably a more pragmatic incrementalist approach and eschewed the idea of privatisation for privatisation's sake. Instead, GLCs are to be run as commercial entities.

    This is not unlike the EISC's recommendations that GLCs should not do national service and only people who can contribute to the businesses of GLCs should be appointed to the boards. The GLCs are to shape up and perform. Otherwise, they may have to be shipped out or, in the words of Temasek's Executive Director, Mdm Ho Ching, be prepared to be had for lunch.

    GLCs are to focus on core competencies, divest non-core businesses, but more importantly, they are to build significant international or regional business. Businesses that are no longer relevant or have no international growth potential are likely to be divested. I will talk a little bit more about the internationalisation aspect later.

    Nonetheless, the "Yellow Pages" rule proposed by the EISC would still be relevant in the case of statutory boards, who should adopt this rule to set up enterprises only if the private sector is not providing or is unable to provide a particular service. And I think this was affirmed earlier by the Minister of State, Mr Raymond Lim. In the past, the private sector was underdeveloped and thus

Column: 900

unable to provide a host of much needed and vital services.

    The private sector has now become much more sophisticated and reached a degree of maturity, as evidenced by the likes of Creative Technology and City Development. They have proven to be highly versatile at adapting to and exploiting evolving market trends and technologies.

    Statutory boards must religiously adopt the principle of not setting up an enterprise unless all avenues to involve private sector enterprises are exhausted. Even so, statutory boards could still seek to be involved with the private sector through joint ventures, or what is currently a global corporate favourite - outsourcing - instead of setting up an enterprise by itself. This would help to create more space and opportunities for the private sector.

    In light of the above principles enunciated by EISC, I fully endorse the three-fold rationale stated in the Temasek Charter for the Government to be in business. And these are to manage strategic, critical resources, such as water, power and gas; to pursue public policy objectives, such as healthcare, housing and education; and to enable Singapore to sprout a second wing - an external wing - so that we, as a nation, can compete beyond the narrow confines of Singapore's geography, or perhaps to quote some famous words from "Star Trek", "boldly go where no man has gone."

    Many large, as well as non-listed, GLCs fall into the first two categories - Group A which is what is referred to as Group A businesses - media, water, power, sea and airports. Additionally, many non-Group A category GLCs are already loosely defined in category (3) and referred to as Group B businesses.

    Let me now deal a bit more with the internationalisation aspect, or what I call, the second D, and that is, Diaspora. I submit that, with some exceptions - notably firms, like the Millennium and

Column: 901

Copthorne Group - private enterprise will probably not attempt to enter, much less, conquer, lucrative overseas markets without some nudging from the Government and GLCs leading the way. Hence, Group B GLCs will undoubtedly play a key role in the internationalisation of Singapore's private firms.

    However, a word of caution is in order here. GLCs must be constantly reminded that they should not internationalise for internationalisation's sake. Based on Singapore Inc's track record till date, Singapore companies that have succeeded in international markets have been rare, and profitable international expansion has even been rarer. But the value of the Singapore brand is undoubtedly high, as experience in rapidly developing countries, like China, demonstrates. There are thus wonderful opportunities for a Singapore Diaspora.

    GLCs must be mindful that the promotion of the external economy is only justifiable if it generates higher returns than the potential growth rate of Singapore without the external economy. The burden must be on the GLCs to deliver superior returns on the external economy to justify their course of action. Expanding aggressively but blindly into international markets could, instead of improving our economic bottom line, do it more harm.

    In my view, the quest for a more diversified earnings base by overseas expansion is a necessary but insufficient condition for category B GLCs to internationalise. IE Singapore, whose role is to grow our external wing, should make every attempt to link these GLCs up with suitable local private sector firms willing and capable of expanding overseas in the chosen markets. This way, definite benefits will accrue to both parties, private and public sectors.

    The third D refers to Detachment. The Temasek Charter has emphasised the commitment of GLCs to be run as commercial entities, detaching ownership by Government from commercial-minded management. Furthermore, they are to strive to be truly international businesses,

Column: 902

with clear strategies on how to get there. Similarly, the EISC's recommendations also favour a commercial approach for GLCs. Indeed, Temasek's choice of the term "TLCs" to describe its large and formidable stable of companies seems to reinforce its desire to de-link itself from the Government. But the question is: "Can it really do so?"

    As the EISC notes, Temasek should make a conscious effort to cast a wide net to attract world-class managerial talent into GLCs, foreign or otherwise. Indeed, Temasek could bring more private sector directors on the boards of its companies and management to ensure a good mix of people, able to give different perspectives and ensure that the companies are run on sound commercial principles - delivering commercial returns.

    To allow a good mix, Temasek should avoid appointing too many Government and SAF scholars - undoubtedly highly intelligent, driven and capable people - to the ranks of senior management of these companies. Undeniably, many of them have subsequently carved out sterling careers in the private sector. However, even though these people are placed in the private sector, they may not necessarily be of the private sector.

    Scholars carefully groomed by the system and attuned to the culture of the public sector, parachuting into key positions in GLCs, may have a propensity to carry with them a Government mindset that does not sit well with the workings of the private sector. I submit that there should be a greater degree of intermingling of public and private sector talents in GLCs. It must never be construed as a zero sum game when a public servant is lost to the private sector, and vice versa. Indeed, the intermingling will serve to enrich both.

    The fourth and final D refers to Divestment. While supporting the spirit of divestment where appropriate, the Temasek Charter does not spell out any definite divestment timetable, as some of my parliamentary colleagues have alluded to earlier. Instead, Temasek notes that it has been progressively divesting its stake

Column: 903

in non-strategic companies and listing some companies to broaden their ownership base. It also states that it will continue to rationalise and consolidate its shareholdings where it is opportune to do so. The argument for the lack of a definite divestment programme is the need to achieve the best price for the unit being divested. If market conditions are not right, it makes no commercial sense to do so.

    Mdm Deputy Speaker, whilst I agree that this is largely a reasonable path to take, and I am certainly not advocating a great GLC sale, we have to be mindful that the cost for not divesting soon enough could be even higher, and that is the killing off of private enterprise. As a compromise, I suggest Temasek perform an annual divestment audit, taking into account other than the usual factors, like capital market conditions, strategic relevance and likely price, the impact on the private sector of divestment or otherwise. Further, subject to suitable safeguards, the divestment audit could be tabled in Parliament for debate. This is another way of putting in place what the EISC has itself recommended - mandatory periodic housekeeping.

    In the divestment programme, Temasek should also not be averse to the dismantling of its companies. Size, though useful, is not always a competitive advantage. Specifically, there should be a proper cost-benefit analysis to determine if the break-up value from the different logical parts of the business exceeds the value of the entity as a unified whole.

    In saying this, I must state that I am not against size for its own sake. I also recognise that the competition law that the EISC speaks of, operates only to break up the abuse of monopoly power, not monopoly itself. But quite apart from what the future competition authorities can and will do, Temasek itself, as arm of the Singapore Government, should proactively ensure that the actions of its subsidiaries do not stifle private enterprise through the sheer weight of its

Column: 904

size and market power. Another model I support is the management buy-out which has been proposed in the recent case of NatSteel.

    There is a need for Temasek to act more decisively in its divestment programme, lest the Charter be construed as mere talk without action.

    In conclusion, I would like to applaud the efforts of the relevant parties in preparing both the EISC documents and the Temasek Charter.

    Since Temasek was formed in 1974 as the Government's investment holding arm, it has grown to include more than 60 major companies, with subsidiaries and associate companies in almost every economic sector, with a workforce of some 150,000. This is more than twice the size of the entire civil service, which is currently reported on the website as about 60,000 strong. Furthermore, the top 22 GLCs are reported to account for 13% of the country's gross domestic product in 1998. GLCs are thus indeed very significant and play an important role in Singapore's economy.

    Madam, I submit that times have changed. GLCs will need multi-industry knowledge, technology assessment capabilities, and financial expertise well in excess of what it now has. Recall the lessons of the conglomerate and its demise.

    Recognising that the private sector provides the best seedbed for enterprise and innovation, it will need all the space it can get - physical, financial and economic. In this regard, the business of government is ultimately not government in business, but government for business - planting, watering, pruning, nurturing - to grow and nurture the future heroes of capitalism that will spearhead the next stage of Singapore's economic development and, in the process, we could convince more would-be quitters to be stayers.

    Madam, I therefore support the Motion.

Column: 905


7.05 pm

    Mrs Fang Ai Lian (Nominated Member): Mdm Deputy Speaker, I rise in support of the Motion to implement the recommendations of the Entrepreneurship and Internationalisation Sub-Committee (EISC). I fully support the recommendation to redefine the role of Government in business and to call on the Government to support local private enterprise. I particularly like the idea that Government-linked companies should work in collaboration and partnership with small and medium enterprises to complement their business rather than to compete with them.

    Much has already been said in Parliament as well as outside as to how GLCs stifle and crowd out private enterprise. However, I would like to say that it is equally important that we do not over exaggerate the negative side of GLCs because, by and large, they have not done too badly. They have done quite a good job. They are run professionally, efficiently and also profitably. They provide a lot of jobs for our people and they also contribute to a significant part of our GDP, some 13%. A handful of them - I am glad that bouquets have also been thrown at GLCs - have helped Singapore establish its international brand name. And it is because of the good reputation caused by GLCs, a lot of local enterprises have been helped in their marketing efforts overseas.

    Because of the hue and cry and criticisms levelled at GLCs, some of them have already begun the process of collaborating with local enterprises. The logistics arm of SembCorp Industries teamed up with Goodpack to make use of their specially developed metal containers to international bulk carriers. We also have CapitaLand with Kinderkids World providing childcare services at their properties abroad. All these are positive developments and ought to be acknowledged. Of course, a lot more can be done and a lot needs to be done.

    Whether private enterprise would have flourished without GLCs is a moot point. But it is clear that GLCs were formed at a time when private enterprise was either

Column: 906

unwilling or unable to get into businesses which GLCs went into. Of course, there are many instances where GLCs slipped their fingers into one pie too many. But most of that is the past, and I think they are also embarrassed. So, let us not harp on it. Let us move on and find the proper solutions.

    The recommendations of the EISC as well as the New Temasek Charter recently unveiled are all steps in the right direction. There is a recognition that Singapore today is not quite the same as it was many years back and, in the new situation, the role of Government in business needs to change. This role, however, need not be changed so quickly and so drastically. Some of us may think that the remaking of Singapore is all about turning Singapore upside down and inside out, but life is not quite so simple as that. Some things can be done, some things cannot be done, short of shooting your own foot.

    GLCs, because of the magnitude of their presence in the marketplace, it would be imprudent to have a sudden divestment of businesses worth billions of dollars, involving hundreds and thousands of jobs. This will surely destroy shareholders' values, and shareholders are Singaporeans. It will destroy shareholders' values and it will destroy jobs. This will not be good for us and clearly, it will not be the right step to take.

    So, we need a much more well-managed and organised approach towards divestment, and I am glad that the EISC as well as Temasek Holdings are taking the positive and right steps in this direction. What is much more important is the development of the entrepreneurial spirit. This is not an easy task, but steps are being taken. They are pushing this goal, but we have to recognise that it is going to be a long haul because we are starting fairly right from the bottom.

    At this juncture, I would like to share with the House a report published by Global Entrepreneurship Monitor (GEM), which is an international body which tracks entrepreneurial activity worldwide.

Column: 907

In its 2001 report, it compared some 29 countries. We fared not so well. We were ranked 27th out of 29. In its 2000 report, we were 19th out of 21. So we are quite far away from the Number 1 position which we would like to occupy and boast about.

    Why is this so? Critics of GLCs would probably jump at this and say, "I told you so! GLCs are crowding off local private enterprises." But the real reasons are quite complex. The GEM report recognises that Singapore has a rather unique challenge and handicap. This is because, as Mdm Deputy Speaker has said, we have a rather small domestic economy. This means that, by necessity, businesses must venture overseas in order to acquire a size that matters. Businesses may argue that if they have had the entire domestic economy to itself, small as it may be, it will give them that start-up advantage. But we have to remember that we operate an open economy. If we do not compete against GLCs, then we will have to contend with MNCs. So, in a way, the GLCs provide a check against MNCs. But, whatever the reason might be, there must be a recognition that because of the smallness of our economy, businesses must, by nature, strike out and acquire a size that matters.

    The GEM report also noted that the Government has already promoted entrepreneurial activity in the technology area. This is a good practical approach, because it is in the cutting-edge of technology and life sciences that we have the greatest chances of success. But even this approach has its pitfalls, as the Internet bubble has taught us a few painful lessons. But the point here is that by playing safe, focusing on a few technology companies, we are actually also going against the grain or the spirit of entrepreneurship, which is not being afraid to fail. Therefore, I would like to urge the Government to promote greater entrepreneurship. It is not just about high-tech; it should also be medium-tech, low-tech and no-tech, because the whole spirit of entrepreneurship is also about the spirit of self-reliance. If we look at the

Column: 908

products and services we use everyday - the food we eat, the clothes we wear, the chairs we sit on - these are no-tech businesses. These are services and products provided by businesses with a few thousand dollars or millions of dollars of turnover. But one thing is common. They are started up by entrepreneurs, either out of necessity or out of a passion, ie, their ability to know that they can do something better than others. So, whatever their motivation, it is important that we encourage and support them, because it is out of a large pool of entrepreneurs that some superstars can emerge.

    We can use the analogy in football, I suppose. Brazil has won the World Cup a few times, and this is because an entire nation is just crazy about football. So, they have a lot of footballers to choose from. All young Brazilian boys play it on every piece of land that they can find. We also celebrated a trawl of four goals in the recent Commonwealth Games. We won in table tennis and badminton, games which are not entirely popular with Singaporeans. But we won because of imported foreign talent. That is not so bad. And this is the same formula which has won us many goals for our economy. We won because of foreign direct investments, and this has helped us to achieve remarkable growth.

    But this is not quite the same. We could have continued this strategy, but the landscape has changed. So it is important that we grow more local entrepreneurs. But it has to be also noted that there is a direct correlation between foreign direct investment and entrepreneurial activity. The GEM report noted that, in the case of Belgium - only Belgium and Japan were ranked below Singapore - it was a country whose economy is very highly dependent on foreign direct investment and international trade, its entrepreneurial activity is abysmally low. So, critics said that this was due to the fact that foreign direct investments just make entrepreneurial activity less attractive. But the GEM report also noted that Belgium did not quite help itself in terms of entrepreneurial training to help shape attitudes and behaviour. So, entrepreneurial training was only present at the

Column: 909

undergraduate and graduate level, but it was totally absent across the system relating to primary, secondary and pre-university level. Therefore, it just did not stimulate the attitudes which were so vital for an entrepreneurial mindset and environment.

    So, perhaps, we too can look at our own education system. Our schools now focus very much on academic results, and our vocational institutes, on technical skills. This orientation has obviously served us well for many years. We will continue to require brilliant academics, competent technicians but, at this stage, we need something more. So we need to weave into our education system creativity, entrepreneurial attributes like dare-to-dream and dare-to-fail. That way, we can develop and shape attitudes amongst our young.

    I would like to end by looking at which are the countries which are ranked well, and what are the lessons we can draw from them. The dark horses were Australia, New Zealand and Mexico. I call them dark horses because they do not really have exactly high-profile economies. But they were ranked very highly in terms of entrepreneurial activity. And this was attributed to the fact that there was a high level of government awareness in this area, promoting entrepreneurship and having an active engagement with entrepreneurial leaders as well. In the case of Mexico, its economy was very much dominated by large public and private monopolies, and yet entrepreneurship is very much alive and thriving. This is because these large public and private companies actually outsource their activities to the small independent businesses which are able to run in a much more agile manner. Hence, the point made on outsourcing many times over.

    Korea was also ranked very highly and this was due to the fact that it was able to address the problems surfacing from the 1997 Asian economic crisis very well. It was able to develop very specific measures, in particular to develop new businesses. As we remake Singapore,

Column: 910

I think there are lessons to gain from the Korean experience.

    Lastly, the great entrepreneurial star - the United States of America. It has been a star for many, many years. This is because its culture embraces change and opportunity seeking. Entrepreneurship is very much regarded as an accepted and highly respected occupation and failure is regarded as an accepted learning experience.

    I think we too can develop a culture which embraces change and opportunity in a big way. We too can make entrepreneurship an accepted and highly respected career and we too can make failure an accepted learning experience.

    Along the way, we must have Government incentives and support. We must have laws and regulations lightened. We must have the GLCs now working more and more in collaboration and in support of local enterprise.

    More than that, we need a complete transformation of the entire nation's attitude towards entrepreneurship. It is a good start. It is a long haul but it is very encouraging.

    On that note, Mdm Deputy Speaker, I support the Motion.

    Dr Gan See Khem (Nominated Member): Mdm Deputy Speaker, I would like to support the Motion by Mr Leong Horn Kee and Mr Inderjit Singh and share in their request for the Government to consider the implementation of some of the key recommendations of the EISC on Government in business.

    The GEM report has accumulated evidence from their research over several

Column: 911

years that documents the significant relationship between entrepreneurship and national economic adaptation and expansion. From the GEM report, it does appear that in less-developed and developing countries where the economy is less dependent on international trade, where there is less extensive social welfare system and the women are less empowered in the economy, necessity entrepreneurship dominates and it is positively related to the state of economic development. India ranks very high in this score.

    On the other hand, in the more developed countries, opportunity entrepreneurship dominates. These SMEs contribute only 35% to our GDP, whilst MNCs contribute 45% and, as

Column: 912

I understand earlier, the GLCs contribute some 13%.

    This formula had worked in the past but we need to continuously improve the share of private entrepreneurial activity and create an environment whereby local enterprise can develop the capabilities, resources and size that would allow them to compete in the regional, if not, the global marketplace. The creation of such an entrepreneurship society can only benefit Singapore's economic development.

    As Singaporeans, we are heartened at the success of our GLCs, particularly in their ability to move into the knowledge, technology and capital intensive sectors, both locally and also in the international arena. GLCs were set up to spearhead the development of the Singapore economy and they had fulfilled their mission. That said, I hope that the GLCs would continue to play a role in spearheading the remaking of the new Singapore economy.

    We appreciate that Temasek Holdings had come forward and shared their new defined Charter and articulated the role of the Temasek-linked companies to all Singaporeans. However, I would like to urge the other sectors of the GLCs including the labour-linked companies (LLCs) (some of my colleagues call them NLCs), the statutory board-linked companies (SBLCs) and the press-linked companies (PLCs) to follow the example set by Temasek and share their strategic roadmap with Singaporeans. I believe that such communication would address the anxiety of the local enterprises in terms of the perceived unfair competition from GLCs.

    TLCs had communicated and informed Singaporeans that they intend to spearhead the development of enterprise and to partner other non-TLCs, including local SMEs, when venturing into more knowledge-based activities and regional markets. TLCs, in this instance, can play the role of the big brother or sister, where the case may be, to invest value-add and partner with the private sector to groom

Column: 913

viable local enterprises to compete effectively in the regional arena. I am sure that local SMEs would look forward to further dialogues and exchanges with TLCs to work out effective and profitable collaborative arrangements. I also hope that over time, our local entrepreneurs will associate TLCs with the acronym, "tender, loving care", signifying a more pro-business Singapore.

    There is a renewed marked shift globally towards private-public partnership (PPP) as an engine for growth. PPP recognises that both the public and private sectors have certain advantages relative to the performance of specific tasks. Thus, by allowing each sector to do what it does best, public services and infrastructure can be provided in the most economically efficient manner. In the United States, over the last couple of years, there have been much renewed intense discussions on how the Government can work better and cost less.

    Recently, this focus has led to discussions as to whether or to what extent the private sector should be performing many of the functions currently performed by the Government. With budget deficit reduction and the downsizing of Government agencies, the American attention on privatisation, competition and efficiency has greatly increased. In Ireland, PPP has been widely implemented, initially through modestly scaled projects, with the aim of combining the best of public and private sector expertise to create value for money and quality outcome.

    PPP has been encouraged through many economic sectors, such as housing, education, healthcare, local service, public utilities and transport. According to the GEM report, Ireland has the highest total entrepreneurial activity within Europe. The World Bank has also articulated their emphasis on private sector participation as engines for growth. In recent years, the World Bank has encouraged private participation not only in infrastructure development but also in human services, most prominently in education, healthcare and social security.

Column: 914



    As Singapore faces major technological transformation and a maturing economy, both the public and private sectors must share the responsibility of defining new national strategies that would unleash human creativity to enable us to innovate and adapt technologies and opportunities to our own needs. Singapore needs to build our own model for public-private partnership. Thus, it is also timely for our public sector to review the potential of PPP in their activities and to share such visions with Singaporeans.

    However, the experience of other countries has reminded us that though the opportunities for privatisation are plentiful, the path to successful business relationships and implementation of PPP nevertheless would face many challenges. I believe that for PPP to work in Singapore, we need to realistically identify the hurdles to successful PPP implementation, to develop the administrative structure to enable PPP to put into practice and to formalise an incentive system that would foster collaboration and cooperation between the two sectors for the benefit and long-term needs of the nation. The success of PPP in Singapore would depend to a large extent, on a well-thought out charter and plan that is effectively communicated to different stakeholders such as the one articulated by Temasek recently. I hope that the other GLCs and relevant Government agencies would also share their plans with us in the near future.

    Unlike TLCs which would primarily play the role as the co-investor, other public sector agencies can participate in many other forms of PPP which may include outsourcing, contract services, build, operate, transfer, and many other types of PPP.

    Successful PPP can only result if there is commitment from top public officials who are willing to be actively engaged and support the concept and taking a leadership role in the development of such partnerships. Equally important is that the private sector partners must have the relevant skills and experience in the specific area of partnership being

Column: 915

considered. Once the partnership has been established, the public sector must remain actively involved in the programme or project not only in terms of monitoring, but also in value-adding. As such, PPP will provide the platform for the creation of more opportunity entrepreneurship, thereby enabling Singaporeans to continue to expand our economy through increased entrepreneurial activities.

    Mr Wee Siew Kim (Ang Mo Kio): Mdm Deputy Speaker, thank you for allowing me to speak on the Motion.

    Perhaps I would start by giving an analogy which encapsulates my opinion on the debate on GLCs and the SMEs. In an ecosystem, there is a dynamic complex of plants, animals and micro-organisms and their non-living environment interacting as a functional unit. Each, regardless of size, has a role to play in the web of life. For example, in the ocean ecosystem, the oceans support a wide variety of plants and animals which co-exist in relative harmony, each fulfilling a specific niche and role they have in the ecosystem. While in any ecosystem there is competition and survival of the fittest, there are also symbiotic relationships. The ecosystem is really a matrix of inter-relations, not just a singular approach or formula. Take, for example, the little cleaner fish in the ocean. How does it survive? Often, tiny micro-organisms fasten themselves to a big fish and make sores on its body. When this happens, the big fish goes to a coral reef where the cleaner fish lives. The cleaner fish hunts all over the fish body, and helps the big fish by eating all these tiny micro-organisms and, in this way, the cleaner fish gets fed and the bigger fish is spared the discomfort. An economy is similar to the ecosystem. As such, there is a place and role for large corporations and smaller enterprises. The difficult part is how do we go about this balancing act.

Column: 916



    Let me share with the House my thoughts on this. Rather than just levelling the playing field in Singapore for the SMEs, there should be more constructive ways to help them grow, compete and survive beyond our shores. The Chinese proverb - give a man a fish, and he would eat for a day; teach a man to fish, and he would eat for the rest of his life - is very true. There is no level playing field in the economic world anywhere. So, why create an artificial environment that will only ensure local survival? What is at stake is continued and global survival.

    Here, I believe there are two key elements which are critical to any GLC versus SME debate. The first is the definition of our economic ecosystem. We must realise that the playing field is not just the domestic market. Rather, the economic ecosystem is well beyond Singapore. We must not run the risk of debating how we should compete locally, ie, keeping the balance in our pond ecosystem while the larger ocean ecosystem, which is globalisation, washes us over and leaves us in its wake.

    In our discussions, we must be mindful that the mission is building establishments out in the world for our descendants, so that wherever we decide to stake out, there is always HQ Singapore. To have such global ambitions, we need a strong home base, just as the SMEs want to build a strong home base, so we should not deny the GLCs the same. A strong home base will better prepare our companies to take on the world. There is an incessant cry that SMEs are being crowded out. When faced with Goliath, David may have just cause to cry foul. But, paradoxically, organisational ecologists have observed empirically that increased dominance of large firms actually creates an environment that is hospitable to the entry of smaller specialist organisations.

    The August issue of Stamford Business further reported that this is seen in industry after industry - breweries, airlines, auditing, music recording, newspaper publishing, manufacturing of hard disks, etc. As large generalist firms tend

Column: 917

to go for the market centre, niches appear around the periphery. In beer parlance, the small craft brewers moved in to provide consumers with a wider variety in taste, colour, form and serving temperature.

    The vibrancy of the local business landscape is borne out by the statistics. In the 10 years, from 1988 to 1998, the number of SME establishments grew by 59%. The same organisational ecologists also subscribe to the red queen theory. Remember the red queen in Lewis Carol's fairytale "Through the Looking Glass". The red queen seems to be running but actually staying on the same spot. What it means is that competition is good, in that a company is forced by direct competition to improve its performance, in turn, pressurising its rivals to do so, thereby creating a virtuous cycle of learning and competition.

    A research has revealed that a lack of domestic competitive experience is a critical disadvantage when a firm is thrust into global competition. Hence, a competitive landscape must be nurtured. So, it is not a question of snuffing out the big boys, neither is it that the SMEs do not have a role in embracing and enhancing Singapore's competitiveness and economic growth. Rather, let us see how we can harness the strengths of the GLCs to nurture and promote the SMEs, so that they can also get bigger, stronger and fly the Singapore flag in the world. Coexistence of the GLCs and SMEs would have to be the way forward, honing our capabilities within our shores, so that once we foray abroad and leaning on brand Singapore, which is one that is already recognisable, one with high regional and global awareness and standing for efficiency, fair dealing and transparency, we will have a much better overall chance of success and survival.

Competitive coexistence

    Here are some of my suggestions. First, let us network and talk. So, what is so difficult about this especially where we proactively do this with overseas businessmen and potential partners? Strangely

Column: 918

enough, I suspect that we do not do enough of this between the GLCs and SMEs. We need a bridge to connect the GLCs and SMEs. Through this bridge, ideas can be exchanged, lessons learned can be shared, new business thoughts may spring forth and partnerships may blossom. These partnerships may be between GLCs and SMEs or even among the SMEs themselves. Perhaps IE Singapore can be the business SDU to bring these parties together. Or the Chambers of Commerce and industry associations can act as catalysts. A forum needs to be created. Just as our successful SDU has dinner talks, tea parties, social activities and match-making capabilities, this business SDU can do the same for GLCs and the SMEs.

    Secondly, GLCs can play an active role in helping SMEs venture abroad by partnering them when they seek new pastures. A business associate, which I think was also mentioned by an earlier colleague, shared with me the observation on Taiwanese businesses venturing into China. When these businesses have identified opportunities in China, they bring along their suppliers with them. Together, they almost replicate their entire supply chain in China, ensuring a better chance of success. They work with people they know best. They link hands and venture out together. It is a united approach with all parties benefitting - an interesting business model worth considering for us in Singapore.

    Our GLCs have a strong home base and are better placed to venture abroad. They also have the management and financial capabilities. So, what is stopping these GLCs from bringing along their local suppliers along with them? It may mean to be more proactive in identifying good SME suppliers with potential to be part of a winning combination. It may also mean helping these suppliers by equipping them with the know-how to improve their efficiency or management, so that they are more ready to weather the perils beyond our shores. This will help shorten the SMEs learning curve by being able to piggy back on the GLCs.

Column: 919



    In SME 21, the often mentioned structural weaknesses of the SMEs tend to be centred around inefficient use of technology, outmoded methods of production, limited ability to tap economies of scale, shortage of professional and technical manpower, insufficient management know-how and professionalism. I believe the emergence of a partnering culture between the GLCs and the SMEs would mitigate, to a large extent, these structural issues. It has to start with the building of trust.

    The SME 21 plan intends to treble the number of SMEs with sales turnover of $10 million or more to 6,000. With such growth, I believe that there are great opportunities that exist, and these cannot remain untapped, just because no one makes the first move or we are focusing our energies on only competing amongst ourselves. IE Singapore's Network China has been successful and Network India is being set up. Can the GLCs not partner some SMEs and tap into these markets together? Perhaps IE Singapore can play the matchmaker, and it must have mechanisms in place, so that the concern of appearing to be partial whenever one SME is being selected over another does not hold back initiatives.

    Clusters created to foray overseas must be based on good business case with the best chance to win. To consciously make this happen, we should reorientate our view of GLCs and judge them on how much their business is derived offshore and how many local SMEs they have spawned or partner with in their ventures.

    Singapore is an economy that has seen a rapid transformation from third to first world in one generation. It is unparalleled. We are unique with unique strengths and constraints. In short, we learn from others but we need to adapt. In trying to transform, we must not throw out the baby with the bath water, as this is said three times today. We must not slay all our sacred cows and then discover that the alternatives are stillborn.

Column: 920



    In conclusion, we must remember that we are Team Singapore. In a team, there are defenders, midfielders and attackers. The ultimate goal is that Singapore should win. In-fighting amongst the players to get choice roles will just jeopardise our chance of winning. We are Team Singapore and in the SME 21 plan, which is characterised as a partnership between Government, Chambers of Commerce, industry associations and the private sector, it should also be expanded to include the GLCs as well. We are no longer only playing home matches. We are in a global match. And in the away games, we must train to win. While the debate is on GLCs, I think there is and must have resolve to ensure that the momentum behind SME 21 does not fizzle out. We must stay the course. As in the ecosystem analogy that I started with, a symbiotic relationship with competition in specific niche areas will have to be one of our formulae for going forward. So, in the Motion which supports competition, which nourishes the spirit and culture of partnerships, and which squarely sets the sight on the external wing, I am supportive.

    Miss Penny Low (Pasir Ris-Punggol): Mdm Deputy Speaker, thank you for allowing me to join in this debate.

    The raison d'etre of GLCs and Temasek has been well documented. The reasons for the GLCs' existence was when the SMEs were not able to access capital on their own, or there were insufficient entrepreneurs that had the capacity to risk large quantum of capital. Singapore then needed the GLCs to build up the strategic industries to put Singapore on firm economic, social and even political pedestals. It was for the sole reason of survival, and the GLCs have done a good job.
