After 37 years of independence and rapid economic growth, our private sector is also a lot more mature and capable. Coupled with the challenges of the new economy in the

Column: 921

global playing field, we need to re-examine our modus operandi, and make relevant the roles of both the GLCs and the SMEs, so that we, as a nation, can strive and thrive.

    Interestingly, I also have an analogy which is based on the ecosystem. Since we are an island, please allow me to use the analogy of fish and water. The GLCs are like fishes that were originally introduced to a pond to promote life, to promote growth. Over time, it keeps spawning and while the pond can still maintain an ecological balance for coexistence, it remains placid. It has now reached the point where the pond has become too small for this growing ecosystem. In order to survive, the big will eat the small fishes and even compete with its own kind to survive. The ecological system is out of balance.

Scepticism and Distrust: Playing Field

    Madam, the private sector reckons the GLCs to be the fishes that have multiplied and grown to a monstrous size in a small pond. Willy-nilly, there appears to be a two-way scepticism and distrust between the big fish (GLCs) and the small fish (SMEs). In fact, some SMEs avoid contact with the GLCs whenever there is a business opportunity for fear that the GLCs may muscle them out of the business. This may well be true as GLCs function as a profit organisation, and have often demonstrated that new entities can be created whenever they want to take advantage of an opportunity. Without the necessary financial muscles and network, the SME simply cannot replicate companies with the same speed or size that GLCs can.

    To illustrate, we have a GLC that prepares, manufactures and distributes food, ranging from chilled meat, ready-to-go meals and even right up to hog auction and abattoir. The original raison d'etre of this GLC was one of strategic defence. But how does the slaughtering

Column: 922

of hogs contribute to the defence of Singapore? GLCs are also found in other non-strategic industries, for example, Internet Service Provider, travel agency, supermarket, real estate development and management, IT and business consultancy, systems integration, outsourcing networking, e-commerce, and so on and so forth. Even more recently, HDB, via its subsidiary firm, HDBay, is also getting into the Local Area Network business! In fact, if we include the NLCs, which is a term coined by Mr Leong Horn Kee, they provide goods and services from cradle to grave. Can we really blame the SMEs for keeping a distance from the GLCs? Perhaps, to be fair to the GLCs, such companies were created so that the GLCs can have better control and it could be part of the risk management strategy. But this is also precisely where the problem lies. If we want to cultivate entrepreneurship, then this mindset must change, both on the SME side and GLC side. Some things are indeed much better left to the private sector. And we need to have more faith in the market forces.

Foster Culture of Partnership

    Beyond SMEs, beyond GLCs, we as a nation in challenging times must come to sell all enterprises as valuable to our economic aspirations. We need to see a vibrant culture of cooperation and partnership between GLCs and SMEs. They both can and must play their role in the remaking of our economic thrust and should receive equal facilitation and support from the Government.

    To continue on my imagery analogy of the fish and water, I would like to see the Government, and perhaps even Temasek Holdings, provide the lead to ease the congestion in this small pond, by digging a trench that would provide alternatives to the contents of this small pond into the open sea of the global economy. Once the monstrous fishes in this small pond enter the open sea, they may no longer be that big. This is where the GLCs and SMEs can come together, support each other and assert themselves in the new environment. I urge the Government to adopt the

Column: 923

recommendation of the EISC to "encourage a culture of partnership between GLCs, MNCs and SMEs and adopt a cluster approach when venturing overseas; and raise the profile of the Local Industry Upgrading Programme (LIUP) and expanding it to promote internationalisation." We need a paradigm shift, we need to promote partnership as a multiplier, and not a zero sum game.

    In fact, as Mr Inderjit Singh had also said, we need to leverage on each other's strength, in order to grow. The SMEs, given their business instincts and acumen, can sniff out the business opportunities while the GLCs can also support with their know-how and process expertise. The GLCs, with their good brand name, can also pull the SMEs along while establishing a beach-head on foreign soil.

    Madam, I urge that the Government also urgently facilitate outlets for these monstrous fishes and guide them towards the open sea. The movement of these monstrous fishes would stir the seabed, throwing up planktons and living organisms to feed the smaller fishes. In time, these smaller fishes will be able to grow, be able to fend for themselves and even establish their own pedigree, their own brand. I do not support the exodus of GLCs, but that GLCs should stick to their original reason for existence, and divest the non-core businesses at a reasonable price over a reasonable period of time.     Assoc. Prof. Dr Yaacob Ibrahim:

    The MP has asked if my Ministry will consider setting up a repository for abandoned babies in residential areas or designated places. While the objective is to protect the baby from danger as well as the anonymity of the parent who abandons the baby, such repositories remain controversial, even in countries where they have been introduced.

    Such repositories, also known as `Baby Drops', may save a life, but they also make it easier for a parent to abandon an infant, thus indirectly encouraging or sanctioning child abandonment.

    Under Singapore law, it is illegal to abandon a baby. This is to underline the inalienable responsibility of parents for the safety and welfare of their children. The `Baby Drop' scheme could unwittingly instigate a parent to commit an offence.
